newsitem.title: INDONESIA: Indonesia's Suharto wants change in campaign rules.
newsitem.headline: Indonesia's Suharto wants change in campaign rules.

text.p: Indonesia's President Suharto said on Saturday the country's election campaign rules must be altered to prevent the recurrence of violence.

"Democracy does not need victims. A general election that ensures a democratic process and proceeds smoothly, peacefully...and does not claim human lives and property losses must become one of our political development agendas in the future," he said in a speech to the nation on the eve of the country's 52nd anniversary of independence.
"We have sufficient time until the next general election -- to think about the best possible ways of conducting general election campaigns," he added.
Last May, Indonesia elected 425 members of the 500-member House of Representatives after an election campaign that was regarded as the most violent during the 30 years of Suharto's rule.

Authorities say more than 300 people died during the campaign, mostly from traffic accidents, while 124 died in a shopping centre fire during a riot in South Kalimantan province. Most of them were people looting the shops in the plaza.

But there were also several other riots during the campaign, which political analysts have said reflected the restlessness of a population increasingly aware of the limitations of Indonesia's political system.

Under Suharto's sometimes autocratic rule, only three political parties -- the ruling Golkar, the Moslem-oriented United Development Party (PPP) and the Christian-Nationalist Indonesian Democratic Party (PDI) -- are allowed to contest elections.
Campaigning is prohibited except for a four-week period preceding general elections and contestants are expected to refrain from direct criticism of each other and the government.
The country's powerful military, which does not vote, are given 75 seats in parliament, many filled by senior generals. Suharto is also a former army general.
Golkar took 74 percent of the votes cast in the election, with the PPP winning 23 percent and the badly fractured PDI picking up three percent.
Indonesia's best-known opposition figure, Megawati Sukarnoputri, was barred from participating in the poll.
Megawati, the daughter of late founding president and Suharto's predecessor, Sukarno, was ousted from the PDI leadership last year by a government-backed rival.
She asked her supporters to boycott the May general election campaign. Megawati stopped short of an illegal call to boycott the elections, although she said she herself would not vote.
Suharto said voter turnout was impressive despite these efforts.
"No one can deny the fact that 90 percent of the Indonesian people exercised their voting right... There are not many countries in the world that equal this feat," he said.
"That was in spite of the fact that around the time of the general elections there were several intensive activities designed to influence the people not to vote," he said.
"Apparently, the Indonesian people were not easily swayed by appeals that would destroy the system and degrade our democratic standing."
"Some disturbances took place that apparently were incited by those who intended to sabotage the general election or at least discredit it," he said.
